dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, Uber is immediately reclassifying all its California drivers as employees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Uber is immediately reclassifying all its California drivers as employees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Because the company believes its workers will still be classified correctly under the new measure, West said Uber will not be automatically reclassifying drivers to be employees in January, when the measure is likely to take effect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a huge shift, especially after they spent, like, 30 million dollars fighting AB5 just to turn around and do this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a huge shift, especially after they spent, like, thirty million dollars fighting AB5 just to turn around and do this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead, Uber says it is prepared to fight any legal challenges in court and has set aside an additional $30 million for a ballot measure to provide workers with other benefits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And CEO Dara Khosrowshahi admitted they should have treated drivers as employees all along—that's pretty bold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And C E O Dara Khosrowshahi admitted they should have treated drivers as employees all along-that's pretty bold.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It sounds like they're trying to repair their image after that court case where they were found guilty of misclassifying workers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It sounds like they're trying to repair their image after that court case where they were found guilty of misclassifying workers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, it seems like Lyft's success with the employee model really pushed them. Logan Green over at Lyft must be feeling pretty vindicated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, it seems like Lyft's success with the employee model really pushed them. Logan Green over at Lyft must be feeling pretty vindicated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As part of its response, Uber is also coordinating with its rival Lyft to propose a new ballot measure that would offer better benefits for their independent contractor workforce, including a base pay rate. Lyft, who also committed $30 million to the ballot measure, said the state had missed an important opportunity when it came to regulating the space.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And now Governor Gavin Newsom is siding with the independent contractor model? It's getting messy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And now Governor Gavin Newsom is siding with the independent contractor model? It's getting messy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both Uber and Lyft stock closed in the green on Wednesday on the news that Governor Gavin Newsom, who had already promised to sign the ball, remains in talks with the companies, as first reported by the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, and did you hear about Tony West? He was their Chief Legal Officer, and now he's actually driving for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, and did you hear about Tony West? He was their Chief Legal Officer, and now he's actually driving for them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, seriously? That feels like a symbolic move, but also kind of wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, seriously? That feels like a symbolic move, but also kind of wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's like they're trying to show they're all in on this new direction, but it's such a sudden flip.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's like they're trying to show they're all in on this new direction, but it's such a sudden flip.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I wonder how drivers are reacting—healthcare and paid time off is huge, but it's gotta feel confusing after years of fighting it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I wonder how drivers are reacting-healthcare and paid time off is huge, but it's gotta feel confusing after years of fighting it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And now Lyft is doubling down on the contractor model? The two are totally diverging.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And now Lyft is doubling down on the contractor model? The two are totally diverging.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As part of its response, Uber is also coordinating with its rival Lyft to propose a new ballot measure that would offer better benefits for their independent contractor workforce, including a base pay rate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's gonna be interesting to see which approach wins out in California.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's gonna be interesting to see which approach wins out in California.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. This could reshape the entire gig economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. This could reshape the entire gig economy.

artist_script:
HostA: So, Uber is immediately reclassifying all its California drivers as employees.
HostB: Yeah, that's a huge shift, especially after they spent, like, 30 million dollars fighting AB5 just to turn around and do this.
HostA: And CEO Dara Khosrowshahi admitted they should have treated drivers as employees all along—that’s pretty bold.
HostB: Right? It sounds like they’re trying to repair their image after that court case where they were found guilty of misclassifying workers.
HostA: Plus, it seems like Lyft’s success with the employee model really pushed them. Logan Green over at Lyft must be feeling pretty vindicated.
HostB: Totally. And now Governor Gavin Newsom is siding with the independent contractor model? It’s getting messy.
HostA: Oh, and did you hear about Tony West? He was their Chief Legal Officer, and now he’s actually driving for them.
HostB: Wait, seriously? That feels like a symbolic move, but also kind of wild.
HostA: Yeah, it’s like they’re trying to show they’re all in on this new direction, but it’s such a sudden flip.
HostB: I wonder how drivers are reacting—healthcare and paid time off is huge, but it’s gotta feel confusing after years of fighting it.
HostA: For sure. And now Lyft is doubling down on the contractor model? The two are totally diverging.
HostB: It’s gonna be interesting to see which approach wins out in California.
HostA: Absolutely. This could reshape the entire gig economy.
